content: Top-ranking police officer of the Singapore Police Force The **Commissioner of Police** is the head of the [Singapore Police Force](/wiki/Singapore_Police_Force) (SPF). The Commissioner is assisted by the [Deputy Commissioner of Police](/wiki/Deputy_Commissioner_of_Police_(Singapore)), and reports to the [Minister for Home Affairs](/wiki/Minister_for_Home_Affairs_(Singapore)). The current Commissioner of Police is How Kwang Hwee. The position was created with the [Police Act](/wiki/Police_Act) of 1856 (and passed in 1857), in response to calls for a full-time dedicated police officer to helm the police force in response to escalating cases of violent crime in Singapore during that period. [Thomas Dunman](/wiki/Thomas_Dunman) was appointed as a Deputy Magistrate and Superintendent of Police in 1843, before he assumed responsibilities as the first full-time Commissioner of Police in June 1857. When [Singapore](/wiki/Colony_of_Singapore), [Malacca](/wiki/Crown_Colony_of_Malacca) and [Penang](/wiki/Crown_Colony_of_Penang) became [Crown colonies](/wiki/Crown_colonies) of the [British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire) in 1867, the role of the police commissioner was expanded to include that of the entire [Straits Settlements](/wiki/Straits_Settlements), with the title changed to [Inspector-General of Police](/wiki/Inspector-General_of_Police). This lasted until the [Japanese occupation of Singapore](/wiki/Japanese_occupation_of_Singapore) in 1942, before the position was restored as the **Commissioner of Police** in 1946 with the return of the British and the gradual instatement of self-governance.
